SourceText: A sphere is a shape like a ball -- it is round in all directions. The moon and the sun are shaped like spheres, though the moon doesn't always look like it.
text: 球形是一种像球的形状 -- 它四面八方都是圆的。 太阳和月亮是球形的, 虽然月亮并不总是看起来这样。

SourceText: Sky was so happy to see Sun that she turned bright blue. The mountains put on their pretty green dresses.
text: 天空很高兴见到太阳，她变成了明亮的蓝色。 山穿上了她们漂亮的绿色裙子。

SourceText: What is the green dress on the mountains made of?
text: 山的绿裙子是由什么做成的？

SourceText: How many clouds are there now? What happened to the other clouds?
text: 现在有多少云朵？ 其他的云朵们怎么样了？

SourceText: Compare the number of things in the sky to the number of mountains with faces. One of them is one more than the other, and one of them is one less than the other -- which is which?
text: 比较天空中物体的数量和有脸的山的数量。 他们中有一个数量比另外一个多, 有一个数量比另外一个少 -- 哪个是哪个？

SourceText: The wind went to sleep. The trees stretched their branches and smiled.
text: 风去睡觉了。 树伸展着他们的枝条笑了。

SourceText: The mountains and trees like the warm weather. Do you like warmer or cooler weather?
text: 山和树喜欢温暖的天气。 你喜欢更温暖的还是更凉快的天气？

SourceText: A cylinder is a shape like a tube or a straw. A broom handle is often a cylinder. The trunks of these trees between the ground and their first branches are cylinders.
text: 圆柱形是一种像管子或者吸管的形状。 扫帚的握柄通常是圆柱形的。这些在地面和树枝之间的树的树干是圆柱形的。

SourceText: What other things around you are in the shape of a cylinder?
text: 你身边有什么其他东西是圆柱形的吗？

SourceText: The clouds were very happy to see Mother Sun again. They went away to play.
text: 云朵们很高兴再次见到太阳妈妈。他们玩耍去了。

SourceText: There are five clouds in the sky. If you add one more for the sun, how many things are in the sky?
text: 天空中有五朵云。 如果你为了太阳加了一朵云, 天空中会有多少东西？

SourceText: Two pages ago there were two clouds. How many more clouds are there now?
text: 在两页之前这里有两朵云。现在多了几朵云？

SourceText: If the clouds were happy to see the Sun, why did they go away?
text: 如果云朵们很高兴见到太阳，他们为什么要离开？

SourceText: Lots of little plants popped out of the earth to say, "Hello." The whole world sparkled.
text: 许多小型植物从地里长出来说你好。整个世界都在闪闪发光。

SourceText: There are butterflies, flowers, stems, and lots of little plants. Count some of these things together.
text: 这里有蝴蝶，花朵，茎秆，以及许多小型植物。 一起数一数他们其中一些有多少。

SourceText: Which group of things are there the most of and which group has the least?
text: 哪一组东西最多，哪一组东西最少？

SourceText: What are some things that plants need to make them happy and grow?
text: 植物需要哪些东西让它们开心成长？

SourceText: Mother Sun shined her light everywhere. "I told you I would be back," she beamed.
text: 太阳妈妈将她的光撒到了每一个角落。 "我告诉你我会回来的，" 她露出了微笑。

SourceText: The rays of the Sun extend very far on this page. Are there days when the rays of the Sun seem to reach all the way to you?
text: 太阳的光在这一页延伸到了很远。 有没有那么几天太阳的光像是一路照到了你的身上？

SourceText: Which are there the least of on this page: trees, mountains, or things in the sky?
text: 在这一页上哪样东西最少: 树, 山, 还是天空中的东西？

SourceText: Which are there the most of? Sometimes there are two things with the same amount with the most -- that's okay, just say both of them.
text: 哪样东西最多? 有时候这里有两样数量相同的东西最多 -- 没关系, 两样都说出来。

SourceText: Mr. Shabangu was the best baker in town. Every morning he woke up at four o'clock to mix and knead the dough for his famous buns, cakes, and biscuits.
text: 沙邦古先生是镇上最好的面包师。他每天早上四点就起床和面揉面，制作他那知名的面包、蛋糕和饼干。

SourceText: Do you like to cook? Baking can be a lot of fun. It usually involves a lot of careful measuring and counting.
text: 你喜欢烹饪吗？烘焙可以带来很多乐趣。通常涉及多次仔细地测量和计数。

SourceText: It looks like there are two rows of four eggs. You can count them by 1's, 2's, or 4's. Which way did you choose? Have you ever seen a carton holding 8 eggs?
text: 看起来那边有两排各四个鸡蛋。你可以按1、2或4的倍数来数出它们。你选择了哪种方式？你见过装着8个蛋的纸盒吗？

SourceText: Why do you think bakers get up early in the morning? Do you like to get up so early that it is still dark outside, or does it seem like you should still be asleep at that time?
text: 你认为面包师为什么早晨要早起？你是喜欢天不亮就早早起床，还是倾向于在那时继续酣睡？

SourceText: By eight o'clock the people of the town were walking past the bakery on their way to work and school. By this time the cakes and buns were almost cooked, and the most delicious smells wafted out of the bakery's windows.
text: 到了八点钟，镇上的人们陆续走过面包店去上班或上学。此时蛋糕和小面包差不多烤好了，最美的香味自面包店的窗口飘散出来。

SourceText: The baker started early so his wonderful food would be ready to eat when people walked by at breakfast time.  Why couldn't the people just wait a little while?
text: 面包师早早开始，是为了让美味的食物刚好于早餐时段人们路过时准备好。人们为什么不能稍等一会呢？

SourceText: The baker could have baked the evening before and then not needed to get up so early. Why didn't he do that?
text: 面包师本可以在前一天晚上烘焙，如此一来就不必那么早起床了。他为什么不这样做呢？

SourceText: This baker has a very small shop! Do you think he has room to cook in, display his baked goods, and have customers walk inside to buy things?
text: 这个面包师的店铺非常小！你认为他有足够的空间来烹饪、展示烘焙食品以及接待顾客走进店购物吗？

SourceText: Many of the people went into the bakery to buy their breakfast. Mr. Shabangu smiled happily at them as he passed them the fresh, tasty cinnamon buns and warm, golden biscuits that were so famous in the town.
text: 许多人走进面包店购买早餐。沙邦古先生微笑着给他们递去新鲜可口且闻名全镇的肉桂面包卷、热金饼干。

SourceText: The clock says it is 1:00. That seems late to be buying breakfast. Have you ever eaten breakfast after noon?
text: 时钟显示现在是1:00。这时候买早餐似乎太晚了。你曾在午后吃过早餐吗？

SourceText: How can you tell the items in the box are fresh and hot?
text: 你如何判断盒子里的东西新鲜并且很热？

SourceText: What in the picture shows that Mr. Shabangu likes his work and cares about the food he makes? Do you have a favorite thing you like to do that you care a lot about?
text: 图片中有什么可以表明沙邦古先生喜欢自己的工作并在意自己做的食物？你有没有特别喜欢并十分在意的事情？

SourceText: But other people were not so lucky. Because they had so little money, the poorer people of the town could hardly ever afford to buy any of the delicious buns, cakes, and biscuits. All they could do was enjoy the lovely smells that drifted out of the bakery windows. When Mr. Shabangu noticed these people sniffing the air near his bakery, he said angrily, "How dare they sniff my delicious smells!"
text: 但其他人就没那么幸运了。因为他们都没什么钱，镇上有些更穷的人甚至永远也买不起那些美味的面包卷、蛋糕或饼干。他们唯一能做的是享受面包店窗口飘出的美妙香味。当沙邦古先生注意到这些人在他面包店附近饱嗅空气时，他愤愤地说道：“他们胆敢吸我的美妙香味！”

SourceText: What do you think? Is it okay for the poor people to enjoy the delicious smells coming from Mr. Shabangu's bakery?
text: 你怎么看？穷人可以享受沙邦古先生面包店溢出的美妙香味吗？

SourceText: Some people are generous with the things they have, while other people don't want to give away something they worked hard to make. Which kind of person do you think tends to be happier?
text: 有些人愿意慷慨分享他们拥有的东西，而有些人却不想平白送出自己辛苦做出的东西。你认为哪一类人往往更快乐？

SourceText: Each of the three loaves of bread on the shelf has three cuts in it. How many total cuts does that make? Did you skip count by 3's, or do you know what 3 times 3 is?
text: 架子上的三条面包各有三个切口。合计是多少切口？你是通过3的倍数跳数的，还是知道3乘以3等于多少？

SourceText: "Those are MY smells. I made them, so they belong to me! If people want to smell my wonderful smells, they should pay for them!" He huffed and puffed and wiped the sweat from his brow, before turning back to the oven to bake some bread and rolls for his lunchtime customers.
text: “那是我的气味。是我创造出来的，所以它们属于我！如果人们想闻到我这些美妙的气味，他们就应该为此付费！”他怒气冲冲地一边说着一边擦去额头的汗，然后转身回到烤箱前，为午餐的顾客烤一些面包卷。

SourceText: Do you agree with Mr. Shabangu? Do we own the aromas we make?
text: 你赞同沙邦古先生的言论吗？我们是否拥有自己制造的香气？

SourceText: There are many ways to sense things. For example, we can touch them. What are some other ways of sensing things?
text: 感知事物的方式有很多种。例如，我们可以触摸它们。还有哪些感知事物的方式？

SourceText: We do restrict some ways of sensing. We typically control who gets to touch or taste our things. Can we control who gets to sense our things in other ways?
text: 我们确实可以限制一些感知方式。通常我们限定谁可以触摸或品尝我们的东西。但我们能限制别人以其他方式中感知我们的东西吗？

SourceText: One old woman especially loved the smells that drifted out of the bakery window every morning. This was Ma Shange who slept on a bench in the park every night.
text: 有位老妇人特别喜欢每天早晨从面包店窗口飘出的香味。她就是每晚都睡在公园长凳上的玛珊戈。

SourceText: Why do you think Ma Shange sleeps on a bench in the park? What does she do when it rains?
text: 你认为玛珊戈为什么睡在公园的长凳上？下雨时她怎么办？

SourceText: Do you ever sleep outside? Do you like being out in nature getting to see the night sky? Is it a little uncomfortable and scary, or does it feel very natural and pleasant?
text: 你是否在户外住宿过？你喜欢在大自然中观赏夜空吗？那种体验是不适且可怕，还是自然而愉悦？

SourceText: Have you ever tried to count all the stars you can see in the sky on a clear night? If the sky is really clear, there are too many stars to count, but it's still fun to try!
text: 你有没有试过在晴朗的夜晚数出天上所有可见的星星？如果夜空非常清澈，星星会多到数不过来。当然，尝试数一数还是很有趣的。

SourceText: A few weeks before, a kind person had given her the money to buy herself a cinnamon bun. She had taken the bun back to the park and ate it very slowly, licking her lips and sharing the last crumbs with the birds.
text: 几周前，一位好心人资助她买了一块肉桂面包。她把面包带回公园，细嚼慢咽。尽管忍不住流口水，她还是和鸟儿分享了最后一些面包屑。

SourceText: That's a lot of birds for her to feed! If she gives three crumbs to each bird, count by 3's to find out how many crumbs she needs to feed them all.
text: 对她来说，要喂的鸟可太多了！如果她每只鸟都给3块面包屑，用3跳数，看看她需要多少块面包屑来喂食它们。

SourceText: If you took one of those buns and broke it into a bunch of crumbs, estimate how many crumbs that would make. An estimate is a best guess as to the quantity of something that is hard to count.
text: 如果你把其中一小块面包弄成一堆碎屑，估算一下碎屑会有多少块。估算是对于难以数清之物在数量上最符合要求的猜测。

SourceText: Ma Shange gave away some of something she likes very much. Why did she do that? Is she happier feeding the birds than if she had eaten those crumbs herself? Have you ever given away something you liked because you knew someone else would enjoy it or need it?
text: 玛珊戈送出了一些她非常喜欢的东西。她为什么这样做？把面包屑喂给鸟儿吃会比自己吃掉更开心吗？你是否曾因为知道某人会喜欢或需要而送出你喜欢的东西？

SourceText: After that, although the old woman didn't have enough money to buy breakfast, she longed for the delicious bun again. So every morning she walked slowly past Mr. Shabangu's bakery, sniffing the air and smiling blissfully at the mouth-watering smell.
text: 之后，尽管老妇人没有足够的钱买早餐，她还是渴望再次品尝美味的面包。于是每天早晨她都会慢慢走过沙班古先生的面包店，嗅着令人垂涎欲滴的香味，面带幸福满足的笑容。

SourceText: It's a little hard to tell, so let's suppose that each piece of bread has 4 cuts in it. What are the total number of cuts for those 6 pieces of bread? Did you skip count by 4's, by 6's, or did you figure it out some other way?
text: 由于难以判断，因此我们假设每块面包上有4切口。那么这6块面包的切口总数是多少？你是通过以4或6跳数还是采用其他方法求出的？

SourceText: Take a quick look and estimate how many buns you see on the lower shelf.
text: 快速浏览一下，估算你在下层货架上看到的面包数量是多少。

SourceText: Now count the buns and see how close your estimate is. There are many ways to count them. One way is to skip count by 2's. How did you count them?
text: 接下来数一数面包，看看你的估算有多接近。数数的方法有很多种，其中之一是以2的倍数跳数。你是如何计数的？

SourceText: Ma Shange's new habit made the baker very angry. As each day went by, he grew angrier and angrier with her. Finally, one winter morning when he was in an especially bad mood, he stormed out of his bakery and grabbed the old woman by the arm. "How dare you steal my smells!" he shouted. "You're nothing but a smell thief!" He wiped his hands on an apron, then pulled it off and threw it back into the bakery.
text: 玛珊戈的新习惯惹得这位面包师很生气。时间一天天过去，他变得愈发愤怒。终于，在一个冬日的清晨，他的情绪糟糕到了极点。他含怒冲出面包店，抓住老妇人的手臂。“你竟敢偷我的香味，”他怒吼道，“你就是一个偷香味的贼！”他用围裙擦了擦手，随后扯下并扔回了面包店。

SourceText: The bricks showing in the wall are rectangles. Rectangles have four straight sides and have corners like the corners of this page. Can you find any other rectangles in this picture? Do you see any rectangles around where you are?
text: 墙上露出的砖块是长方形的。长方形有四条直边以及像本页纸一样的四角。你能在这张图中找到其他长方形吗？你在周围看到任何长方形了吗？

SourceText: What do you think, is the baker right? Should Ma Shange be forced to stay away?
text: 你对整件事有什么看法？面包师言行正确吗？玛珊戈应该被迫离开吗？

SourceText: Notice how the bricks in different rows are offset from the row above. This is always done. Guess why having the bricks all lined up would make the wall weaker.
text: 注意不同行的砖块是如何相互错位的。错位铺砖的方式历来如此。猜猜看为什么把砖块都排成一行会使墙更加脆弱。

SourceText: "This is the last day this cheeky woman will steal my smells!" he shouted. And with these words, he dragged Ma Shange off to the court to see judge Ngwenya. The judge was sitting down at his huge, shiny desk when the angry baker stormed in, dragging the quivering and confused Ma Shange with him.
text: “今天是这个厚颜无耻的女人偷我香味的最后一天了！”他叫嚣着。说罢，他把玛珊戈拖到法庭去见恩格文雅法官。愤怒的面包师拽着瑟瑟发抖又一头雾水的玛珊戈横冲直入，而此时法官正坐在他那巨大而闪亮的办公桌前。

SourceText: Point out the rectangles in this picture. Why do you think rectangles are used so often in creating rooms and buildings?
text: 指出这张图片中的矩形。你认为矩形为什么会被频繁用于建造房屋和各类建筑？

SourceText: Triangles, which are 3-sided figures, are stronger, more rigid, and keep their shape better. Why not build everything out of triangles?
text: 三角形是有三条边的图形，更坚固、更刚性，并且能更好地保持形状。为什么不把一切都建成三角形的呢？

SourceText: Have you seen buildings that use shapes other than rectangles. It's fun to find places constructed out of unusual shapes!
text: 你看过使用矩形以外的形状建造的建筑物吗？寻找一些由不寻常的形状构建的地方是很有趣的。

SourceText: "Good morning," said the judge in his deep voice. "Sir," said Mr. Shabangu furiously, "I demand justice! I wish to lay a complaint against this woman. Every day for the last three weeks, she has walked past my bakery early in the morning when my delicious smells are at their best, and stolen them. I demand that she pays for those smells!"
text: “早上好，”法官用他的深沉声音说道。“先生，”沙邦古气愤地说道，“我要求公正！我想对这个女人提出诉讼。过去的三周里，她每天一大早就趁着我那些怡人香气最浓郁时走过面包店，偷走香味。我要求她为那些香味付费！”

SourceText: This is the first time in the story the baker has asked for payment for his smells rather than for his baked goods. Imagine how silly it would be if he had a sign in his shop that listed costs for different smells.
text: 这是故事中面包师第一次要求为他的香味而不是他烤的食物付费。试想一下，如果他的店里有一块各种香味的价格标示牌，那将是多么荒谬。

SourceText: Smells can be wonderful and delightful and can fill us with happiness. However, what are they worth? How much do you think a good smell is worth?
text: 香味可以美妙而令人愉悦，得我们充满幸福感。然而，该怎么衡量它们的价值呢？你认为一种好的香味值多少钱？

SourceText: Some people buy perfumes with special smells, and some people buy herbs and other foods mainly for the aromas they will provide for their food. Those are some forms of buying smells.
text: 有些人购买含有特殊香味的香水，有些人购买香草和一些食材主要是为了赋予食物芳香。这些是购买香味的部分情形。

SourceText: The judge scratched his big, bald head for a moment. Then he cleared his throat. "Fair enough," he said to the baker. "Justice will be done." He turned to Ma Shange. "How much money do you have on you, Madam?" he asked.
text: 法官挠着他那大秃头，思考了好一会儿。然后他清了清嗓子。“好吧，”他对面包师说，“正义终将得以伸张。”他转玛珊戈。“夫人，你身上有多少钱？”他问道。

SourceText: There are even more rectangles in this picture. If you look for them, you will find rectangles almost everywhere people have made things.
text: 这张图片中有更多的矩形。如果你寻找它们，你会发现矩形几乎遍及所有人类制造的物品。

SourceText: What do you think the judge is going to do with Ma Shange's money? How will the judge put a price on the baker's smells?
text: 你认为法官将如何处置玛珊戈的钱？法官对面包师的香气将如何定价？

SourceText: How do you think this story is going to end?
text: 你认为这个故事会如何结束？

SourceText: "Only two rands," stammered Ma Shange. "Well," said the judge, "hand it to me, please." Meekly, Ma Shange reached into the pocket of her tatty old cardigan and pulled out two one rand coins. She handed them to the judge. He took them, thanking her politely.
text: “只有……两兰特。”玛珊戈结结巴巴地答道。“好吧，”法官说“请把它交给我。”玛珊戈温顺地从破旧羊毛衫的口袋里掏出两枚1兰特硬币，给法官。法官接过后，礼貌地向她道谢。

SourceText: The judge asked her for all the money she had in the world. It seems pretty harsh for her to give her only money to the baker, even if it is only 2 rands (equal to about 15 cents in the US or Europe right now).
text: 法官要求她交出所有的钱。这似乎过于严厉了些——让她把仅有的钱给面包师，即使那只是2兰特（现在约合美国或欧洲的15美分）。

SourceText: Rands are used as currency in the country of South Africa. Their smallest coin is the 5 cent piece. How many of those coins does it take to make 1 rand? If you haven't learned how to divide, count by 5's and keep track of how many 5's you use.
text: 兰特是南非的流通货币。他们最小的硬币是5分面值。多少枚这样的硬币才够1兰特？如果你还没有学会除的用法，那就以5的倍数计数，并记录你使用了多少个5。

SourceText: South Africa also has a 10 cent piece. How many of those coins does it take to make 1 rand?
text: 南非还有10分面值的硬币。多少枚这样的硬币才够1兰特？

SourceText: Then he shook the coins in his big fist, so that they made a clinking sound. "This is my judgement," he said to the baker. "The punishment must fit the crime. Therefore the sound of Ma Shange's money is the payment you will get for the smells she stole. And now I wish you a good day." The baker looked thoughtful. Then, realizing how unreasonable he had been, he turned slowly and walked out of the room.
text: 随后法官摇晃着他的大拳头，发出叮叮当当的声响。“这就是我的判决，”他对面包师说，“惩罚必须与罪行相称。因此，玛珊戈的钱的声音就是对你被她偷走香味的补偿。好了，祝你今天快乐。”面包师若有所思地看了看，之后意识到了自己的无理取闹，慢慢转身走出了房间。

SourceText: A good end to a dispute brings a sense of justice and rightness to all the parties involved. Did the baker feel he had been dealt with fairly? Did the baker learn something important on that day?
text: 一场争端的良好结局会让所有当事人觉得公正和恰当。面包师是否觉得自己受到了公正的对待？面包师在那天学到了什么重要的东西吗？

SourceText: It was good the baker finally realized he had been unreasonable. It would have been even better if the baker had done more for Ma Shange. An apology to Ma Shange would have been an important step.
text: 对面包师而言，最终意识到自己的不理智是好事。如果面包师能为玛珊戈多做点什么，那就更好了。向玛珊戈道歉应当是重要的一步。

SourceText: What else, if anything, do you think the baker should do for Ma Shange?
text: 如有可能，你认为面包师还应该为玛珊戈做些什么？

SourceText: The judge smiled kindly at Ma Shange, and handed her back her money. "Now, Madam," he said pulling a brown paper bag from his briefcase, "would you care to join me for breakfast? These buns are still warm, I bought them only half an hour ago."
text: 法官对玛珊戈和蔼微笑，并把钱递还给了她。“现在，夫人，”他边说边从公文包里拿出一个棕色的纸袋，“你愿意和我一起吃早餐吗？这些小圆面包还很热乎，我买回来才半个小时。”

SourceText: The judge realized how poor and hungry Ma Shange was. He showed the kind of generosity that the baker should have shown all along.
text: 法官意识到玛珊戈是多么贫困和饥饿。他展现出了那位面包师长久以来本该表达的慷慨。

SourceText: Helping others is tricky and involves some hard questions. Who do you help, how do you help, and how much do you help?
text: 帮助他人件复杂的事，涉及一些尖锐的问题：你帮助谁、如何帮、帮多少？

SourceText: Have you ever given aid to someone in need of help? We all need help at times. We can't help everyone, but there are times when we can help and make an important difference in another person's life.
text: 你是否曾向需要帮助的人施以援手？我们总会在某些时候需要帮助。即使不能帮到每一个人，但有时我们仍可能向他人提供援助并为其带来生活上的重大改善。

SourceText: One day Tortoise was walking through the countryside. He was looking for something. He gazed into the distance and squinted at the grass. Then he walked past Snail.
text: 有一天，乌龟在乡间漫步。他在找什么。他凝视着远处，眯起眼睛看着草地。然后他路过了蜗牛。

SourceText: Tortoise is looking for his house. Do you think he forgot it or did he never know where it was? Do you know where Tortoise's house is?
text: 乌龟正在找他的家。你认为他是忘了还是从未知道它在哪里？你知道乌龟的家在哪里吗？

SourceText: Do you know where Snail's house is?
text: 你知道蜗牛的家在哪里吗？

SourceText: Where do you live? Is your house easy to find, or do you need help finding your house sometimes?
text: 你住在哪里？你的房子容易找到吗，还是有时候需要帮助才能找到你的房子？

SourceText: "Are you looking for something?" Snail asked. "Yes, Snail, I'm looking for my house. Have you seen it, by any chance?"
text: "你在找什么吗？" 蜗牛问道。"是的，蜗牛，我在找我的家。你碰巧见到了吗？"

SourceText: Can you remember having trouble finding something and discovering it was easy to find all along?
text: 你是否记得找某样东西时发现它其实一直很容易找到？

SourceText: When you don't think of how to do something that is easy to do, how do you feel? Does it frustrate you? People overlook things all the time, it's very easy to do!
text: 当你不去想如何去做一些容易的事情时，你会有什么感觉？这让你沮丧吗？人们经常忽略事物，这很容易发生！

SourceText: It's fun to imagine animals talking together like this. If you could talk with an animal, what would you ask them?
text: 想象动物像这样一起交谈是很有趣的。如果你能和动物交谈，你会问它们什么？

SourceText:
Snail said, "No, I haven't, but I'll help you look!" She climbed onto Tortoise's shell.

Tortoise walked on with Snail on his back. They looked and looked, but there was no sign of a house. The sun was high in the sky.
text:
蜗牛说：“不，我没有，但我会帮你找！”她爬上了乌龟的壳。

乌龟背着蜗牛继续前行。他们找了又找，但没有找到房子的迹象。太阳高高挂在天空中。

SourceText: Why didn't Snail and Tortoise walk together side by side?
text: 为什么蜗牛和乌龟没有并排走？

SourceText: The average speed of a tortoise is about 20 times faster than a snail. The average speed of a person is about five times faster than a tortoise.
text: 乌龟的平均速度约为蜗牛的20倍。一个人的平均速度约为乌龟的5倍。

SourceText: Why did the story mention where the sun is? Do you think something interesting is going to happen with the sun?
text: 为什么故事提到太阳在哪里？你认为太阳会发生什么有趣的事情吗？

SourceText:
A little later they passed Sparrow.

"Are you looking for something?" asked Sparrow. "Yes, Sparrow, I'm looking for my house. Have you seen it, by any chance?" Sparrow said, "No, I haven't, but I'll help you look!"
text:
过了一会，他们路过了麻雀。

"你在找什么吗？" 麻雀问。"是的，麻雀，我在找我的家。你碰巧见到了吗？" 麻雀说："没有，但我会帮你找！"

SourceText: The leaves of each branch are paired up except for one leaf at the very end. When things are paired up with one left over, that means there are an odd number of them.
text: 每个树枝的叶子都成对出现，只有最后一片叶子除外。当事物成对出现，只有1个剩余时，意味着他们有奇数个。

SourceText: When you have an odd number of something, you can't share it equally with two people. If you can share something equally, that means you have an even number of things. Two and four are examples of even numbers. Can you think of some other even numbers?
text: 当你有奇数个东西时，你不能平均分给两个人。如果你可以平均分享一些东西，那意味着你有偶数个。二和四是偶数的例子。你能想到其他一些偶数吗？

SourceText: It's even trickier to think of numbers that can be shared equally by three people? Can you think of any examples of this?
text: 想找到可以被三个人平均分配的数字更加困难。你能想到一些这样的例子吗？

SourceText: He flapped his wings and he whizzed away. "But you’re going too fast for me," complained Tortoise. Sparrow came back. "Alright, then I’ll hop on too."
text: 麻雀拍打着自己的翅膀，飞走了。 "但你对我来说太快了，" 乌龟抱怨道。麻雀回来了。 "好吧，那么我也跳上去吧。"

SourceText: The average speed of a sparrow is at least 10 times faster than a person, so it is about 50 times faster than a tortoise!
text: 麻雀的平均速度至少比一个人快10倍，所以它大约比乌龟快50倍！

SourceText: What a huge range of speeds! Sparrow is 50 times faster than Tortoise, and Tortoise is 20 times faster than Snail!
text: 速度的范围真是太大了！麻雀比乌龟快50倍，而乌龟比蜗牛快20倍！

SourceText: Fortunately for Tortoise, Sparrow and Snail are very light to carry. Have you ever carried a heavy load for a long distance?
text: 幸运的是，对于乌龟来说，麻雀和蜗牛都很轻。你曾经长距离地携带过沉重的负载吗？

SourceText: Tortoise carried on, with Snail and Sparrow perched on his shell. They looked and looked, but there was no sign of a house. The sun had inched lower in the sky.
text: 乌龟继续前行，蜗牛和麻雀栖息在他的壳上。他们找了又找，但没有找到房子的迹象。太阳在天空中缓缓下降。

SourceText: Why does the story keep mentioning where the sun is? Where was the sun the last time it was mentioned?
text: 为什么故事一直提到太阳在哪里？上一次提到太阳在哪里？

SourceText: Mentioning the sun's position is a way for the story to let us know that time is passing and it is getting later in the day.
text: 提到太阳的位置是故事告诉我们时间在流逝，天色渐晚。

SourceText: It is getting later and the group is still not successful. What do you think happens next? WIll Tortoise give up?
text: 现在时间越来越晚，这个小队仍然没有成功。你认为接下来会发生什么？乌龟会放弃吗？

SourceText: A little later they passed Ladybird. "Are you looking for something?" asked Ladybird. "Yes, Ladybird, I'm looking for my house. Have you seen it, by any chance?"
text: 过了一会，他们路过了瓢虫。"你在找什么吗？" 瓢虫问。"是的，瓢虫，我在找我的家。你碰巧见到了吗？"

SourceText: There are many names for ladybirds -- they are also called ladybugs, lady beetles, lady clocks, and lady flies. There are many thousands of types of ladybirds in the world!
text: 瓢虫有许多名字-金龟子，金龟，花大姐。世界上有成千上万种瓢虫！

SourceText: Although ladybugs do not fly for very long, they can briefly fly as fast as a sparrow!
text: 虽然瓢虫飞行的时间不长，但它们可以短暂地飞得像麻雀一样快！

SourceText: Ladybirds can have different numbers of spots. How many spots have you seen on a ladybird?
text: 瓢虫的斑点数量可以不同。你在瓢虫身上看到了多少斑点？

SourceText:
Ladybird said, "No, I haven't, but I'll help you look!" She hopped onto Tortoise's back and on he went, with Snail and Sparrow and Ladybird on his back.

They looked and looked, but there was no sign of a house. A breeze started to blow.
text:
瓢虫说："不，我没有，但我会帮你找！" 她跳到了乌龟的背上，然后他们一起前行，背上还有蜗牛、麻雀和瓢虫。

他们找了又找，但没有找到房子的迹象。一阵微风吹来。

SourceText: Tortoise is lucky. A ladybird is another very light animal to carry.
text: 乌龟很幸运。瓢虫是另一种非常轻盈的动物。

SourceText: It is getting later in the day and a breeze is starting to blow. Hmm ... What do you think will happen with the weather?
text: 天色越来越晚，微风开始吹拂。嗯... 你认为天气会发生什么变化？

SourceText: It's hard to see all of Tortoise's shell. What's your best estimate for how many yellow regions are in his shell? An estimate is an educated guess.
text: 要看到整个乌龟的壳很难。对于他的壳上有多少个黄色区域，你的最佳估计是什么？估计是一种有根据的猜测。

SourceText: A little later they passed Mouse. He was making a garland of daisies. "Are you looking for something?" asked Mouse. "Yes, Mouse, I'm looking for my house. Have you seen it, by any chance?"
text: 过了一会，他们路过了老鼠。他正在编织雏菊花环。"你在找什么吗？" 老鼠问。"是的，老鼠，我在找我的家。你碰巧见到了吗？"

SourceText: Estimate and then count the number of daisies. Do the same for the number of dark spots on Tortoise.
text: 先估计一下，然后数数雏菊的数量。对乌龟身上的黑色斑点也做同样的事情。

SourceText: Are there more daisies or spots, and how many more are there?
text: 雏菊和斑点哪个更多，比另外一个多了多少？

SourceText: What happened to all the animals Tortoise was carrying? Where do you think they went?
text: 乌龟携带的所有动物都怎么了？你认为它们去了哪里？

SourceText: Mouse said: "No, I haven't, but I'll help you look!" She hopped onto Tortoise's back. "Wait, I can't leave my flowers behind." Tortoise waited. Mouse stretched and stretched and scooped up her daisies.
text: 老鼠说："不，我没有，但我会帮你找！" 她跳上了乌龟的背。"等等，我不能把我的花留在后面。" 乌龟等着。老鼠伸展着身体，伸手捧起她的雏菊。

SourceText: How much help have the other animals been? Do you think Tortoise could have done just as well alone?
text: 其他动物帮助了多少？你认为乌龟独自一人是否能做好？

SourceText: Which kinds of things do you like to do with others, and which do you like to do by yourself?
text: 你喜欢和别人一起做哪些事情，又喜欢独自完成哪些事情？

SourceText: Estimate and count the leaves blowing around Tortoise. Are your estimates getting better?
text: 估计并计算围绕乌龟飘动的树叶。你的估计有变得越来越准确吗？

SourceText: Tortoise walked on, with Snail and Sparrow and Ladybird and Mouse on his back. They looked and looked, but there was no sign of a house. The wind swept leaves off the ground and swirled them around Tortoise's feet. He was tired. "You lot are heavy," he sighed.
text: 乌龟继续前行，蜗牛、麻雀、瓢虫和老鼠都在他的背上。他们找了又找，但没有找到房子的迹象。风吹起了树叶。他感到疲倦。"你们都很重，"他叹了口气。

SourceText: The wind is getting stronger. The weather is changing!
text: 风越来越大了。天气变了！

SourceText: Do you notice the weather changing when a storm comes? The wind picks up and there are more clouds.
text: 当暴风雨来临时，你是否注意到天气的变化？风变得更大，云也变得更多。

SourceText: Do you enjoy the excitement of a storm coming in? Sometimes there is lightning and thunder! Do you enjoy the thunder, or is it scary, or perhaps some of both?
text: 你喜欢暴风雨来临时的兴奋吗？有时会有闪电和雷声！你喜欢雷声吗，还是它让你感到害怕，或者两者都有？

SourceText: The wind got stronger. The sky turned dark. "Oh, where is my house?" asked Tortoise. Thunder roared in the hills. Lightning flashed in the distance. Drip-drip came the rain.
text: 风越来越大。天空变暗了。"哦，我的家在哪里？" 乌龟问道。雷声在山间回荡。闪电在远处闪烁。雨水滴滴答答。

SourceText: Why does Tortoise want to find his house so urgently now?
text: 为什么乌龟现在如此迫切地想找到他的家？

SourceText: Usually, people look for shelter when a storm comes. Do you see anyplace that could give them shelter?
text: 通常，当暴风雨来临时，人们会寻找庇护所。你看到哪里可能可以给他们提供庇护？

SourceText: Have you ever been caught out in an open area when a storm came up suddenly? If you don't mind getting wet, it can be fun to experience being in the storm!
text: 你曾经在暴风雨突然来临时被困在露天区域吗？如果你不介意淋湿，体验在风暴中的感觉可能会很有趣！

SourceText: The wind swirled and whipped. It blew Snail and Sparrow and Ladybird and Mouse right off Tortoise's back.
text: 风卷起然后呼啸而过。它把蜗牛、麻雀、瓢虫和老鼠一起从乌龟的背上吹落。

SourceText: There are many parts of this picture that show how strongly the wind is blowing things around. Describe a few of them.
text: 这幅图中有许多部分显示了风有多强，描述其中一些。

SourceText: Is the rain coming down vertically (straight up and down), or is the wind blowing the rain diagonally?
text: 雨是垂直下落的吗（直上直下），还是风把雨吹斜了？

SourceText: The diagonal rain is all falling in the same direction. Parallel lines are lines that go in the same direction. Find some parallel lines around where you are.
text: 对角雨都是朝着同一个方向下落的。平行线是指方向相同的线。在你周围找一些平行线。

SourceText: And then came the hail, tip-tip-tip. Tortoise got such a fright he shrank into his shell. It was warm and cozy in there. "Oh, here is my house!" smiled Tortoise.
text: 然后冰雹来了，啪啪啪。乌龟被吓得缩进了他的壳。里面温暖而舒适。"哦，这就是我的家！" 乌龟微笑着说。

SourceText: Tortoise solved his problem when he got distracted and stopped looking for the answer. Sometimes, when we focus too hard on something, it's hard to have new ideas and find an answer.
text: 当他分心并停止寻找答案时，乌龟解决了他的问题。有时，当我们过于专注于某事时，很难产生新的想法并找到答案。

SourceText: Have you ever stopped thinking about something, relaxed for a while, and then suddenly realized the answer? It can be very powerful to let a different part of your brain work on a problem!
text: 你有没有停止思考过某事，放松一会，然后突然意识到答案？让大脑的不同部分处理问题可能非常有效！

SourceText: Tortoise found his shell was a warm and cozy place, and that meant home to Tortoise! What does home mean to you?
text: 乌龟发现他的壳是一个温馨而舒适的地方，对他来说，那就是家！家对你意味着什么？

SourceText: Oh, here is Tortoise's house! said Snail and Sparrow and Ladybird and Mouse.
text: "哦，这就是乌龟的家！" 蜗牛、瓢虫、麻雀和老鼠说。

SourceText: The hail coming down on Tortoise's shell probably made a lot of noise. Imagine the racket! Have you ever heard hail falling on a roof or hard surface?
text: 下在乌龟的壳上的冰雹可能发出很多噪音。想象一下这个吵闹的场面！你曾经听过冰雹落在屋顶或坚硬表面上的声音吗？

SourceText: It is easy for Tortoise to carry his home wherever he goes. Is your home easy to carry around, or is it a structure that would be very hard to move?
text: 对乌龟来说，随身携带他的家非常容易。你的家是否方便携带，还是一个很难搬动的结构？

SourceText: A nice thing about a home, if it is big enough, is that it can be shared with friends. It looks like a happy time for our group of friends in the story!
text: 关于家的一个好处是，如果足够大，就可以与朋友共享。在故事中，我们的这一群朋友似乎度过了一段愉快的时光！

SourceText: Odongo and Apiyo waited for the school holidays to come.
text: Odongo 和 Apiyo 等待学校的假期。

SourceText: They look excited. Do you suppose they have big plans for their holidays?
text: 他们看起来很兴奋。你觉得他们的假期有大计划吗？

SourceText: Are there holidays that you get excited about?
text: 有没有让你兴奋的假期？

SourceText: Tell a story about something you did during a recent holiday.
text: 讲一讲你在最近假期期间做了些什么。

SourceText: It was time for them to visit their grandmother.
text: 是时候他们去看望奶奶了。

SourceText: Did you ever get so excited about something that you had trouble sleeping?
text: 你有没有曾经因为某件事而兴奋得睡不着觉？

SourceText: Rectangles are shapes with four straight sides and corners like those on this page. Point to all the rectangles you can find on this page.
text: 长方形是有四个直边和四个角的形状，如本页所示。指出你能在这页面上找到的所有长方形。

SourceText: Point to some of the rectangles around where you are.
text: 指出在你周围的长方形。

SourceText: They drove past mountains, wild animals, and farms.
text: 他们开车经过高山、野生动物和农场。

SourceText: Count together all the wild animals you see on this page.
text: 数一数你在此页面上看到的所有野生动物。

SourceText: When you add two children to the five other animals, how many animals are there all together? What is two more than five?
text: 如果你在五只动物中添加两个孩子，一共会有几只动物？比五多两个等于多少？

SourceText: Point to and describe the pairs of animals here.
text: 指出并描述这里的成对动物。

SourceText: After a while, Odongo and Apiyo fell asleep.
text: 过了一会儿，Odongo 和 Apiyo 睡着了。

SourceText: Some people have trouble sleeping sitting up. Can you fall asleep while you're sitting?
text: 有些人坐着睡觉有困难。你坐着的时候能睡着吗？

SourceText: The girl is sleeping with her mouth open -- do you think she is snoring?
text: 这个女孩张着嘴睡觉——你觉得她在打鼾吗？

SourceText: Describe the colors of some of the strips in this picture. There are yellows, blues, and greens on the bag, and yellows, oranges, and reds on their seat.
text: 描述一下图中条纹的颜色。袋子上有黄色、蓝色和绿色，座位上有黄色、橙色和红色。

SourceText: They found their grandmother resting under a tree.
text: 他们发现奶奶正在树下休息。

SourceText: Do you have friends or relatives you like to go on trips to visit?
text: 你有喜欢去旅行看望的朋友或亲戚吗？

SourceText: Remember a happy visit you had. What do you like to do when you visit someone?
text: 想一下你去过的一次愉快的拜访。你看望人家时喜欢做什么？

SourceText: What will these two do with their grandmother? Will they hear stories, cook meals, and go on walks together?
text: 这两个人会跟奶奶一起做什么？他们会一起听故事、做饭、散步吗？

SourceText: Grandmother danced and sang. The children gave her presents.
text: 奶奶又唱歌又跳舞。孩子们给她送了礼物。

SourceText: What do you like to get as a present?
text: 你喜欢收到什么礼物？

SourceText: What feels so good about getting a present from someone?
text: 收到别人送的礼物为什么感觉这么好？

SourceText: The background on the last page had blues and greens. This one has yellows and oranges. What feels different to you when you see the colors on these two pages?
text: 上一页的背景有蓝色和绿色。这页有黄色和橙色。当你看到这两页上的颜色时，你有什么不同的感觉？

SourceText: Grandmother blessed Odongo and Apiyo in a traditional way.
text: 奶奶用传统方式给 Odongo 和 Apiyo 给予祝福。

SourceText: Giving a blessing is a solemn and dear thing.
text: 给予祝福是一件庄严而亲切的事情。

SourceText: The background color has changed again. How does it make you feel?
text: 背景的颜色又变了。这让你感觉怎么样？

SourceText: Is this an exciting or calm part of the story? Does the blue color enhance that feeling?
text: 这是故事中令人兴奋还是平静的部分？蓝色会增强这样的感觉吗？

SourceText: Odongo and Apiyo played with butterflies and birds.
text: Odongo 和 Apiyo 与蝴蝶和小鸟玩耍。

SourceText: Have you ever seen birds and butterflies with so many colors?
text: 你见过如此五彩缤纷的小鸟和蝴蝶吗？

SourceText: Can you count the number of butterflies, or is that a bigger number than you can count?
text: 你能数清楚蝴蝶的数量吗？还是蝴蝶的数量比你能数得要多？

SourceText: The colors in the background form ever larger circles -- they are called concentric circles. How do all these colors together make you feel?
text: 背景中的颜色形成更大的圆圈——它们被称为同心圆。所有的颜色在一起给你什么感觉？

SourceText:
They climbed trees.

They splashed in the water of the lake.
text:
他们爬树。

他们在湖中溅起水花。

SourceText: How did Odongo get up into a tree with no low branches?
text: Odongo 怎么能爬上一棵没有低矮树枝的树？

SourceText: How many branches are on this tree? Did you count all of them including the small ones, or just the large ones?
text: 这棵树上有几根树枝？你是把小的都数了，还是只数了大的？

SourceText: Do you go in a lake or pond with your shoes on? Why do you suppose Apiyo did that?
text: 你会不会穿着鞋子进入湖泊或池塘？ 你觉得 Apiyo 为什么这样做？

SourceText:
They were tired.

They fell asleep before finishing their dinner.
text:
他们很疲倦。

他们还没吃完晚饭就睡着了。

SourceText: Have you ever been so tired that you fell asleep in the middle of eating?
text: 你有没有因为太累而饭吃到一半就睡着了？

SourceText: Do you think they slept at the table all night?
text: 你觉得他们整个晚上都趴在桌上睡觉吗？

SourceText: Some of the lines in this picture are straight, like the boards on the table, and some are curved, like the edges of the bowls. Look around you. Do you mostly see straight or curved lines?
text: 图中的有些线条是直的，比如桌子上的木板; 有些线条是弯曲的，比如碗的边缘。 看看你的周围。你看到最多的是直线还是曲线？

SourceText:
They helped grandmother.

They collected eggs and picked vegetables.
text:
他们帮了奶奶。

他们收集鸡蛋、采摘蔬菜。

SourceText: Point at and describe all the pairs of things in this picture.
text: 指出并描述图中所有成对的东西。

SourceText: Of the eggs Apiyo is holding, how many can you see?
text: 在 Apiyo 拿着的鸡蛋中，你能看到几个？

SourceText: Do you like helping out with chores?
text: 你喜欢帮忙做家务吗？

SourceText: Grandmother taught Odongo and Apiyo how to cook different foods.
text: 奶奶教 Odongo 和 Apiyo 怎么烹饪不同的食物。

SourceText: Do you like helping with the cooking sometimes?
text: 你喜欢帮忙做饭吗？

SourceText: Do you have any favorite foods you like to help with?
text: 你有什么最喜欢的食物会烧吗？

SourceText: One of the pleasures of traveling is getting to eat new foods. Do you like eating new foods?
text: 旅行的乐趣之一就是品尝新食物。你喜欢尝新食物吗？

SourceText:
Odongo took grandmother's cows to graze.

They ate a neighbor's crops.
text:
Odongo 带着奶奶的牛去吃草。

它们吃了邻居的庄稼。

SourceText: Looking at Odongo, the neighbor, and the cows, what is each of them feeling?
text: 看着 Odongo、邻居和奶牛，每个人都有什么感受？

SourceText: Do you think Odongo will be given a second chance after this mistake?
text: 你觉得 Odongo 在犯错误之后还会有第二次机会吗？

SourceText: When you make mistakes, are you given another chance?
text: 你犯错的时候，你会有第二次机会吗？

SourceText: They went to their grandmother's stall at the market.
text: 他们去了奶奶市场上的摊子。

SourceText: Who is the new woman in this picture and what is she doing?
text: 照片中的新女人是谁？她在做什么？

SourceText: What is grandmother's umbrella for? Is it raining?
text: 奶奶的伞有什么用处？在下雨吗？

SourceText: Count all the different kinds of food grandmother is selling.
text: 数一数祖母正在出售的所有不同的食品。

SourceText: In the evening, they helped grandmother to count her money.
text: 他们晚上帮奶奶数钱。

SourceText: Can you tell that it is evening from this picture?
text: 从这张照片你能看出现在是晚上吗？

SourceText: Do you sometimes get to count money? If you do, is it fun to do?
text: 你会数钱吗？如果你会，数起来有趣吗？

SourceText: When you count things, do you come up with faster ways to do it? For example, counting things in pairs can be twice as fast.
text: 当你数数的时候，你会用更快的方法吗？比如，成对数数的速度可以提高两倍。

SourceText:
Soon, the holidays were over.

Grandmother packed food for their journey.
text:
假期很快就结束了。

奶奶为他们的旅途准备了吃的。

SourceText: The children look happy. Are they happy about leaving?
text: 孩子们看起来很高兴。他们是对离开感到高兴吗？

SourceText: This is the first time we're seeing Odongo's hat. Is it a present from his grandmother?
text: 这是我们第一次看到 Odongo 的帽子。这是奶奶送给他的礼物吗？

SourceText: Their clothes have lots of colors. How many colors are in the clothes you are wearing?
text: 他们的衣服有很多种颜色。你身上的衣服有几种颜色？

SourceText:
The children did not want to leave.

"Grandmother, come with us."
text:
孩子们不愿意离开。

“奶奶，你跟我们一起走吧。”

SourceText: What are the children feeling in this picture?
text: 孩子们在这幅画中感觉怎么样？

SourceText: What did their grandmother say when the children asked her to come with them?
text: 孩子们邀请她跟他们一起走，奶奶怎么说？

SourceText: The children and their father make three people. When you add one more for their grandmother, how many people is that all together?
text: 孩子们和他们的父亲组成了三个人。如果再加上祖母，总共有多少人？

SourceText:
Odongo and Apiyo hugged grandmother.

"Goodbye, grandmother," they said.
text:
Odongo 拥抱了奶奶。

“再见，祖母。” 他们说。

SourceText: Do you have a hard time saying goodbye to people you care a lot about? Does it make you feel sad?
text: 你是不是觉得与关心的人告别很难受？这会让你感到悲伤吗？

SourceText: Their arms and legs come in pairs. Count them by counting by 2's.
text: 他们的手臂和腿是成对的。成对数一数它们。

SourceText: How do the number of arms compare to the number of legs?
text: 手臂的数量与腿的数量相比, 哪个更多？

SourceText: What is better, city life or village life?
text: 城市生活和乡村生活哪个更好？

SourceText: How do the number of girls compare to the number of boys?
text: 女孩的数量与男孩的数量相比，谁更多？

SourceText: If you combine the three girls with the three boys, how many children are there? What is three more than three?
text: 如果把三个女孩和三个男孩加起来，有几个孩子？三加三等于多少？

SourceText: Instead of counting them as three plus three more, count them by 2's and see if you get the same number.
text: 不要将它们数为三加三，试试成对数，看看能不能得到相同的数字。

SourceText: Oh, no!
Lulu is scared of something. She is holding that book very tightly -- perhaps her fear has something to do with the book?
text: 露露害怕什么。她紧紧地拿着那本书——也许她的恐惧与这本书有关？

SourceText: What are some things that scare you?
text: 有什么让你害怕的事情吗？

SourceText: What do you do when you are scared? Do you go to someone or maybe find a safe place?
text: 当你害怕的时候你会怎么做？你是去找人还是找个安全的地方呢？

SourceText: Lulu, it is time to go, calls Ma.
text: “露露，该走了，”妈妈说着。

SourceText: Lulu is running away from her mother. Where do you think she will hide?
text: 露露正在逃离她的母亲。你觉得她会藏在哪里？

SourceText: What do you think is Lulu's favorite color? How can you tell?
text: 你觉得露露最喜欢的颜色是什么？你怎么知道？

SourceText: Is Lulu walking or running? How can you tell?
text: 露露是正在走路还是正在跑步呢？你怎么知道？

SourceText:
Where is Lulu?

Is she under the sofa?
text:
露露在哪里？

她在沙发底下吗？

SourceText: Lulu is hiding. Do you see Lulu?
text: 露露躲起来了。你看到露露了吗？

SourceText: Count together the cushions and window panes.
text: 一起数垫子和玻璃窗。

SourceText: Are there more or less cushions than window panes? What is the difference -- how far apart are the two numbers?
text: 垫子比玻璃窗多还是少？有什么区别——这两个数字相差多少？

SourceText: Is she behind the curtain?
text: 她在窗帘后面吗？

SourceText: That's a clever disguise for Lulu. Why does her clothing make her stand out?
text: 这对露露来说是一个聪明的掩饰。为什么她的衣服使她显现出来呢？

SourceText: Count together the number of legs on the lamp table. Do you have any tables around you with that many legs?
text: 一起数一下台灯桌子有几个桌脚。你旁边附近有这么多桌脚的桌子吗？

SourceText: The number of legs on the lamp table is one less than the number on the couch.  Three is one less than what number?
text: 台灯桌子的桌脚比沙发上的垫子少一个。那么什么数字少一个是三呢？

SourceText:
Where is Lulu?

Is she next to the stove?
text:
露露在哪里？

她在炉子旁边吗？

SourceText: Guess where Lulu is hiding in the kitchen.
text: 猜猜看露露藏在厨房的哪里。

SourceText: Count the cabinet knobs together.
text: 一起数橱柜的把手。

SourceText: Point at all the round things you can find in this kitchen -- there are quite a few.
text: 指出你能在这个厨房里能找到所有圆形的东西——有很多。

SourceText: Is she in the cupboard?
text: 她在橱柜里吗？

SourceText: Once again, Lulu picked a clever hiding place, but her colors don't fit in with the colors in the kitchen.
text: 再一次，露露选择了一个巧妙的藏身之处，但是她的颜色与厨房的颜色不相配。

SourceText: A rectangle is a four-sided shape like this page. Count the rectangles you see on this page.
text: 长方形就像是这个页面的四边形。数一数你在这个页面上看到的长方形。

SourceText: A cylinder is a shape like a jar with straight sides. There are five cylinders on the top shelf (the bowl is not a cylinder). How many are there on Lulu's shelf? Is it the same number?
text: 圆柱体是一个像罐子一样有直边的形状。顶层架子上有五个圆柱体（碗不是圆柱体）。露露躲藏的架上有多少个？是同一个数目吗？

SourceText: Lulu, it is time to go! Where are you? calls Ma.
text: “露露，该走了！你在哪里？”妈妈叫着。

SourceText: Lulu blends in better this time. Do you see her?
text: 露露这次融入得比较好。你看到她了吗？

SourceText: So many things to count! Point at and count together the blocks on the floor, the dolls, and the drawings on the wall.
text: 有很多事物要数一数！地板上的积木、玩偶和墙上的图画，都要一起数数。

SourceText: Which group of things is the largest and which is the smallest?
text: 哪一组东西最大，哪一组最小？

SourceText:
There you are! says Ma.

"I do not want to gooo!"
text:
“你在这里啊！”妈妈说。

“我不想要离开！”

SourceText: Lulu is still holding her book tightly. Do you think Lulu is afraid her mother will take it away?
text: 露露仍然紧紧地握着她的书。你觉得露露害怕她妈妈会把它拿走吗？

SourceText: Lulu seems like she can be difficult when she doesn't get her way. How are you when you don't get your way?
text: 露露似乎在她不顺心的时候会很难相处。当事情没有按照你的方式时候你会如何？

SourceText: Lulu's room has many rectangles. How many can you count?
text: 露露的房间有很多长方形。你能数出几个？

SourceText:
We have to go, says Ma.

"But I really like this one!"
text:
“我们得走了，”妈妈说。

“但我真的很喜欢这本书！”

SourceText: Lulu's book looks very big compared to Lulu. Do you think her book is really that big?
text: 露露的书看起来比露露还要大。你觉得她的书真的那么大吗？

SourceText: Do you have a favorite book or story that you like to look through or have told to you? Have you heard the story many times?
text: 你有喜欢的书或故事你喜欢看或是有人告诉过你吗？你听过很多次这个故事吗？

SourceText: There are many kinds of stories. There are scary ones, funny ones, and some are adventures. Do you have a favorite type?
text: 有很多不同种类的故事。有可怕的，有趣的，还有一些是冒险的。你有喜欢的类型吗？

SourceText: This building has many rectangles. Most buildings use rectangles a lot for their sides and windows.
text: 这座建筑物有很多长方形。大多数建筑物的侧面和窗户都使用长方形。

SourceText: Triangles are three-sided shapes, and pentagons are five-sided shapes. There is a famous building called the Pentagon because it is made in the shape of a pentagon.
text: 三角形是有三个面的形状，五角形是有五个面的形状。有一个著名的建筑叫五角大楼，因为它是五角形的。

SourceText: Why do you suppose buildings are not often made in the shape of a triangle or circle? Have you seen any buildings like that?
text: 你认为建筑物为什么不经常被盖成三角形或圆形？你见过那样的建筑物吗？

SourceText: Where are they going? What does that big book on top of the building tell you about what this building is?
text: 他们要去哪里？楼顶的那本大书告诉你这栋楼是什么？

SourceText: What is going to happen to Lulu's book at this library?
text: 露露的书在图书馆会怎么样？

SourceText: Do you have a place where you can borrow books near where you live? Have you ever borrowed books there?
text: 你住的地方附近有可以借书的地方吗？你曾经在那里借过书吗？

SourceText: I really like this one!
text: “还有这个！”

SourceText: She found a new book very quickly. It didn't take Lulu long to forget about her old book.
text: 露露是一个非常热情的人。有些人会表达自己的感受，而另一些人则比较安静。你是属于哪一种的呢？

SourceText: How does Lulu feel about this new book? How can you tell?
text: 你认为她会想带多少本书回家？

SourceText: The windows behind Lulu have four sides and are almost rectangles. How are they different from rectangles?
text: 你附近有图书馆吗？你喜欢从图书馆借书吗？

SourceText: And this one!
text: “还有这个！”

SourceText: Lulu is a very enthusiastic person. Some people display their feelings a lot and others are quieter with them. Which are you?
text: 露露是一个非常热情的人。有些人会表达自己的感受，而另一些人则比较安静。你是属于哪一种的呢？

SourceText: How many books do you think she will want to take home?
text: 你认为她会想带多少本书回家？

SourceText: Do you have a library near you? Do you like to check books out of the library?
text: 你附近有图书馆吗？你喜欢从图书馆借书吗？

SourceText:
And this one! 

"And this one!"
text:
“还有这个！”

“还有这个！”

SourceText: How many Lulus are there in this picture? Why did the artist draw more than one?
text: 这张图画里有多少个露露？为什么把她画的不止一个？

SourceText: To count as Lulu grabs books, you would keep adding "one more" each time she added a book. What is one more than zero? What is one more than one? You can count as high as you like this way!
text: 要算露露拿的书，你可以在她每次拿一本书的时候就“加一”。比零多一是什么？比一多一是什么？你可以如此的一直往上加！

SourceText: Libraries are supposed to be quiet places. Do you think Lulu should be running around?
text: 图书馆应该是保持安静的地方。你认为露露应该到处跑吗？

SourceText:
See, you return books and borrow more, says Ma.

"YAY!"
text:
“知道吗，你还了书，就可以借更多，”妈妈说。

“太好了！”

SourceText: Why isn't Lulu sad about having to return her old book?
text: 为什么露露不会因为还她的旧书而感到难过？

SourceText: Count together the books on the counter.
text: 一起数柜台上的书。

SourceText: How many books do you think Lulu is checking out? What is the largest number you know?
text: 你认为露露借了多少本书？你知道的最大数字是什么？

SourceText: Where is Lulu now?
text: 露露现在在哪里？

SourceText: Lulu checked out a lot of books! Can you count them all?
text: 露露借了很多书！你能数一数有多少本吗？

SourceText: Do you think Lulu likes to look at and read books?
text: 你认为露露喜欢看书吗？

SourceText: Do you?
text: 你也喜欢吗？

SourceText: I have lost my bat, and I cannot find it.
text: 我的球拍不见了，我找不到它了。

SourceText: Though you can only see five of them, there are six panes in the window. What else is there six of?
text: 虽然您只看到其中的五个窗格，但事实上是有六个窗格在窗户上。还有什么也是六个？

SourceText: The number of rungs on the ladder is one more than the number of panes -- how many? The number of panes you can see is five, which is one less than the total number of panes.
text: 梯子上的梯级数比窗格数多一个——是多少呢？您可以看到的窗格数为五个，这个数目比窗格总数少一个。

SourceText: Rectangles have four straight sides and corners like those on this page. Point to and describe the rectangles in the picture.
text: 矩形有四个直边和角，就像这幅画上的一样。用手指着并且描述图片中的矩形。

SourceText: I looked behind the door. It was not there.
text: 我走到门后去看。球拍不在那里。

SourceText: Did you notice the girl outside the window?
text: 你注意到窗外的那个女孩了吗？

SourceText: The bat is not behind the door -- could it be inside the box?
text: 球拍不在门后面——那它会在盒子里吗？

SourceText: A box is a 3-dimensional shape with rectangles on every side. Do you see anything else similar to a box? (the door)
text: 盒子是一个3 维形状，每边都有矩形。你还能找到其他类似盒子的东西吗？ （比如，门）

SourceText: I looked for it on the shelf. I could not find it there.
text: 我在架子上找。我在那里还是找不到。

SourceText: The window bangs into the shelf when it opens. That seems like a bad design!
text: 窗户打开时会碰到架子。这似乎是一个很糟糕的设计！

SourceText: Do you think this shelf is too high for a child's room?
text: 你觉得这个架子在小孩的房间来说是否太高了呢？

SourceText: There's that girl riding around again. Notice that the buildings behind her are shaped like big boxes. A lot of buildings are.
text: 那个女孩又在外面把脚踏车骑来骑去。请注意，她身后的建筑物形状就像一个大盒子。很多建筑都是这样的形状。

SourceText: I looked for it under the bed. Not there either.
text: 我到床底下找。球拍也不在那里。

SourceText: The girl's dress matches the bag hanging by the door. Do you think the bag is hers?
text: 那个女孩的洋装和挂在门边的包包很相配。你认为这个包包是她的吗？

SourceText: Can you think of a place the boy hasn't looked?
text: 你能想到一个男孩还没有看过的地方吗？

SourceText: Vertical lines are lines that go up and down. How many vertical pieces are there to the blue frame on the side of the bed? The number of spaces between those vertical pieces is one less. How many is that?
text: 垂直线是一条由上到下，由下到上画出来的线。床边的蓝框框有多少垂直线？这些在两个垂直线中间的空格数量比垂直线少一。有多少的空格呢？

SourceText: I searched inside the box. There was no sign of it.
text: 我在盒子里搜索。没有任何球拍的踪迹。

SourceText: The boy's shirt has a stripe on it. Do you see other stripes in this picture? Do you see stripes around where you are?
text: 男孩的衬衫上有一条条的条纹。你在这张照片中有看到其他的条纹吗？你可以在你所在的地方找到任何条纹吗？

SourceText: Pink is a light shade of red. If you include pink, how many things are red in this picture?
text: 粉红色是淡淡的红色。如果粉红色包括在里面，这张照片中有多少东西是红色的？

SourceText: If you don't count pink, you get one less thing that is red. How many is that?
text: 如果你不把粉红色数进去，你得到的答案就是比红色的东西少一。那会是多少？

SourceText: I searched the attic. It was not there.
text: 我到阁楼寻找。球拍不在那里。

SourceText: The boy has looked in a lot of places. How long do you look for something before you give up?
text: 这个男孩已经在很多地方找了。在放弃之前，您会花多长时间寻找？

SourceText: When you have trouble finding something, what are some places you end up finding it?
text: 当你找不到东西时，你最终会在哪些地方找到它？

SourceText: Notice that the window no longer bangs into the shelf. Did the shelf move?
text: 请注意，此时窗户打开时不再会撞到架子了。架子被移动了吗？

SourceText: I looked here, there, and everywhere. I could not find it anywhere.
text: 我看了这里，那里，到处都看了。我哪里都找不到球拍。

SourceText: Looking at his face, what do you think the boy is feeling?
text: 看看男孩的脸，你觉得这个男孩现在的心情是什么？

SourceText: Have you ever lost something and never found it?
text: 你有没有曾经丢过东西而且从来也找不到？

SourceText: The girl is smiling in the window. Do you think she knows where the bat is?
text: 那个女孩在窗外微笑。你认为她知道球拍在哪里吗？

SourceText: Where is my cat?
text: 我的猫在哪里？

SourceText: This cat is very good at hiding. The dark black of this cat helps it hide.
text: 这只猫非常善于躲藏。这只猫身上深黑色的毛有助于祂躲藏。

SourceText: What kinds of places would make it easy to see this cat?
text: 在什么样的环境里可以让您很容易地看到这只猫？

SourceText: Where do you like to hide?
text: 您喜欢在哪里躲藏？

SourceText: Is it under the bed?
text: 猫是否躲在床底下？

SourceText: Was the cat under the bed before the boy looked there?
text: 猫是否在男孩探索床底下以前就已经躲在那里了？

SourceText: This bed cover has lots of colorful stripes. Count how many different colors it has.
text: 这张床单上有多种颜色的条纹。数一数它有多少种不同的颜色。

SourceText: The walls in this room have a free form design that doesn't repeat. Have you  seen walls like this before?
text: 这个房间的墙壁是透过自由风格设计出来并且图案没有重复。您曾经见过如此设计的墙壁吗？

SourceText: Is it on top of the cupboard?
text: 猫是否躲在柜子的上面？

SourceText: Instead of being on top of the cupboard, the cat is inside it.
text: 猫并不是在柜子的上面，而是在柜子里面。

SourceText: This cupboard has a beautiful design. How many colors does it have?
text: 这个柜子的设计很漂亮。它是由几种颜色组合而成的？

SourceText: Talk about the shapes and patterns on the cupboard doors.
text: 一起来谈一谈柜子门上的形状和图案。

SourceText: Is it behind the couch?
text: 猫是否躲在沙发后面？

SourceText: The cat is very easy to see right now. Too bad the boy is looking in the wrong place.
text: 您现在可以很容易地看到这一只猫在哪里。不巧的是，这一个男孩往错的地方寻找了。

SourceText: Point at the strong colors on this page: red, orange, yellow, green, blue, and brown.
text: 请指出这一页图片上面显眼的颜色：红色、橙色、黄色、绿色、蓝色和棕色。

SourceText: Which colors of the rainbow are missing from the room?
text: 房间里少了哪些彩虹的颜色？

SourceText: Is it next to the trash can?
text: 猫是否躲在垃圾桶旁边？

SourceText: The cat must be very fast and quiet -- he was next to where the boy is now.
text: 这一只猫一定很敏捷而且非常安静——它曾经出现在男孩现在所在之处的旁边。

SourceText: Count the red bricks just below the window.
text: 我们来数一数窗户下面的红砖块。

SourceText: There are many straight lines in this picture. Point to some curved lines.
text: 在这一幅画里有许多直线。用手指指出弯曲线。

SourceText: Is it inside the basket?
text: 猫是否躲在竹篮里？

SourceText: Which part of the cat is not inside the SOAP box?
text: 猫身体的哪一个部分不是在肥皂盒里面？

SourceText: What is inside the basket? Is that where the cat sleeps?
text: 竹篮里有什么？那是不是猫睡觉的地方？

SourceText: Notice that the wall does not line up with the squares of the floor.
text: 请注意，墙壁与正方形的地砖没有对称。

SourceText: Is it outside the house?
text: 猫是否在屋外面？

SourceText: That poor boy is always looking in the wrong place.
text: 这一个男孩总是往错的方向去寻找。

SourceText: Do you think the boy ever finds the cat, or will the boy give up?
text: 您觉得这一个男孩最终会找到那一只猫吗，还是他会放弃？

SourceText: This is the same wall pattern as on the last page, but the floor is a different color!
text: 这一页墙壁的图案与前一页相同，但是地砖的颜色不同！

SourceText: Here it is!
text: 猫在这里！

SourceText: It looks like the cat is in a cupboard or under a sink.
text: 看起来那一只猫躲在柜子里或者在水槽下面。

SourceText: Was the cat playing a game with the boy?
text: 那一只猫跟这个男孩在玩游戏吗？

SourceText: What will the boy do with the cat now? Maybe he will feed it or play with it? What do you think?
text: 这一个男孩将会对那一只猫做什么呢？也许他会喂它或者跟它玩？您认为呢？

SourceText:
A long time ago, deep in the forests, King Leopard began to think about the future.

He thought, "I'm getting old and one day, I'm going to die. A wise ruler should pick a successor while still young and healthy."

But how could King Leopard choose? He loved all the members of the animal kingdom the same!
text:
很久以前，在大森林的深处，豹王开始思考未来。

他心想：“我日渐衰老，终有一天我将死去。一个英明的统治者应该趁着年轻健康时选好一位继任者。”

但是豹王可能会怎么选择呢？他对动物王国的所有成员都同等喜爱！

SourceText: If you were going to pick a leader, which skills would you want them to have?
text: 如果你要选择一位领导者，你希望他们具备哪些技能？

SourceText: Guess what King Leopard will look for in a successor. Do you think he will look for the largest, the fastest, or the friendliest animal?
text: 猜猜豹王将在继任者身上寻找什么特质。你认为他会选择最大的，最快的，或者最友好的动物吗？

SourceText: Count together all the tree trunks you can see. Can you count that high?
text: 一起数数你能看到的所有树干。你能数到那么多吗？

SourceText:
King Leopard had an idea. He sent his messengers out into the forests. He told them to ask all the animals of the kingdom to come to the palace.

He was going to have a big party and he was going to make an important announcement.

Away the messengers ran, to all four corners of the forest.
text:
豹王有了一个主意。他派遣使者进入森林，让他们召集动物王国的所有动物前来宫殿。

他将要举办一个盛大的派对，并宣布一个重要的消息。

使者们跑向森林的四个角落。

SourceText: How many messengers does the King have? Are there enough to go to four corners? How many more does he need?
text: 豹王有多少个使者？足够去四个角落的吗？还需要多少个？

SourceText: Do you think the forest really has four corners?
text: 你认为森林真的是四个角吗？

SourceText: What does the writer mean by the phrase "all four corners of the forest?" If forests don't have four corners, what shape are they?
text: 作者使用短语“森林的四个角”想要表达什么意思？如果森林没有四个角，那它们是什么形状的？

SourceText:
On the night of the party, all the animals were at the palace. They sang and they danced and had a great time.

After the moon had risen above the trees, King Leopard came and stood in the middle of the clearing. The animals stopped their singing and dancing. They listened quietly as their king began to speak.
text:
派对当晚，所有的动物都在宫殿内。它们载歌载舞，玩得非常开心。

月亮爬上树梢以后，豹王来到空地中央站定。动物们停止歌唱和跳舞。随着它们的王开始讲话，它们安静地聆听。

SourceText: How many animals can you count in this picture? Are there more animals or more trees?
text: 你能在这张图片中数出多少只动物？是动物多还是树木多？

SourceText: How many animals do you think are in the forest? 10, 20, 30, ... ? A forest usually has hundreds or even thousands of animals, so this will be a very large party!
text: 你认为森林里有多少只动物？10、20、30...？森林里通常有数百甚至数千只动物，可想而知者必定是一个非常盛大的派对！

SourceText: Have you ever seen a non-human animal dance?
text: 你见过非人类的动物跳舞吗？

SourceText: He cleared his throat and said, "I've been thinking that it's time for me to pick a successor. But because I love all of you equally, I can't decide who among you is most worthy. So I've decided to let a contest decide for me."
text: 他清了清嗓子后说道：“我一直在想，是时候挑选一个继任者了。但由于我同等地爱着你们每一位，我无法决定你们之中谁最有资格。因此我决定让一场比赛为我做出选择。”

SourceText: Some of these animals would usually hunt some of these other animals. Can you think of some examples in this picture of animals who would hunt and others who would be hunted?
text: 这些动物中的一部分通常会捕猎另外一部分。你能想出这张图片中哪些动物可能是猎人，哪些可能是猎物吗？

SourceText: What kind of contest would be good for picking a successor? Would you have a race to see who can run the fastest or longest?
text: 什么样的继任者选择赛才算是好的？你会来一场比赛看看谁跑得最快或者最远吗？

SourceText: What would be good contests if you want to find the largest or the strongest?
text: 如果你想找到最大或最强的动物，哪些比赛比较好？

SourceText: King Leopard held up a spear. He said, "The first one among you who can throw this spear up into the sky and count to ten before it touches the ground, will be my successor."
text: 豹王举起一支长矛。他说道：“你们之中谁能第一个将这支长矛抛向天空，并在它触地之前数到十，谁将成为我的继任者。”

SourceText: Will this contest produce a good successor? Predict which animal is going to win.
text: 场比赛会产生一个好的继任者吗？预测哪只动物将获胜。

SourceText: Some of the animal skins have stripes, some have spots, some are segmented, and some have just one color. Do you see any that involve more than two colors?
text: 一些动物的皮肤上有条纹，一些有斑点，一些有分段，还有一些仅有一种颜色。你有看到超过两种颜色的吗？

SourceText: How many of these animals have horns, antlers, or tusks? Are there more of these animals than the other animals on this page?
text: 这些动物中有多少只是长着犄角或獠牙的？它们比本页中其他动物多一些吗？

SourceText:
As King Leopard finished talking, the animals heard a loud noise from behind them. They turned around and saw elephant stomping through the crowd to the front.

"Move out of my way. I'm the biggest, I should be king," said Elephant.
text:
豹王话音刚落，动物们就听到身后传来一阵巨声。他们转身发现，大象正踏步穿过兽群而来。

“让开，我是最大的，我应该做国王。”大象说道。

SourceText: Did the Elephant listen to the King? Was being the biggest important to the King?
text: 大象听国王讲话了吗？对国王来说，成为最大的动物重要吗？

SourceText: When we have our own ideas about the way something should be, we sometimes don't listen to others. Can you think of a time when you were like the elephant and didn't listen well?
text: 当我们对某件事情有自己的想法时，就不太愿意听取别人的意见。你能想到自己某一次像大象一样没有好好倾听吗？

SourceText: A lion is often called the King of the Jungle. Do you think a lion will win this contest and be the next king?
text: 狮子通常被称为丛林之王。你认为狮子会赢得这场比赛并成为下一任国王吗？

SourceText:
Elephant took the spear and held it up with his trunk. He put his head back and threw the spear up into the sky. "One! Two! Three! Oh!" Elephant cried.

The spear hit the ground on the count of three. Elephant was angry and started stomping. King Leopard told him, "You've had your chance."

And so Elephant had to leave.
text:
大象接过长矛，用鼻子卷起。他抬头后仰，把长矛抛向天空。“一！二！三！哦！”大象大喊道。 

长矛在数到三时落地。大象生气了，开始跺脚。豹王对他说道：“已经给过你机会了。”

于是大象只好离开。

SourceText: Does it help to get angry when you lose? How do you feel and what do you show to other people when you lose?
text: 失败时生气有帮助吗？当你失败时，你的感受及你向外人所展露的是怎样的？

SourceText: There are many four-legged animals in this picture. Name some animals that don't have four legs.
text: 这张图片中有许多四条腿的动物。说出一些不是四条腿的动物。

SourceText: An odd number is a number that can't be split into two equal parts -- 7 is an example. Can you think of any animals that have an odd number of arms or legs?
text: 奇数是指不能被分成两等份的数字，例如7。你能想到有奇数条腿或胳膊的动物吗？

SourceText:
After Elephant left, the animals started to talk excitedly amongst themselves. They were again disturbed by a loud noise coming from the back of the crowd.

Boar came charging through saying, "Get out of my way. Get out of my way. I'm going to be king. I've got the biggest muscles. I'm the strongest. I should be king."
text:
大象离开后，动物们开始相互兴奋地交谈。这一次他们又被兽群后方传来的巨大声响打断。

野猪大叫着直冲过来：“让开，让开。我要当国王。我有最大块的肌肉，我是最强壮的。我应该成为国王。”

SourceText: Boar did not listen to the King either. Do you think the King wants someone who is the strongest?
text: 野猪也没有听从国王的话。你认为国王想找最强壮的那个吗？

SourceText: Do you think leaders need to be good listeners to help them know how to lead?
text: 你认为领导者需要成为优秀的倾听者，以帮助他们了解如何领导吗？

SourceText: In this picture, there is only one of most of the animals. Can you spot the animals that there are more than one of?
text: 在这张图片中，大多数动物只有一只。你能找到有多于一只的动物吗？

SourceText:
Boar leaned back, clenched the spear, and threw it into the sky. "One! Two! Three! Four! Five! Oh!" he shouted.

The spear dropped on the count of five. He was so angry. He fumed and threw clouds of dirt into the air.

Leopard told him "Boar, you only throw once and you've had your chance." Boar had to leave.
text:
野猪向后仰身，紧握长矛，然后将其投向天空。“一！二！三！四！五！哦！”他高喊道。

长矛在数到五时掉落下来。他很恼火，怒气冲冲地扬起一团团尘土。

豹王对他说：“野猪，你只能投一次，你的机会已经用掉了。”野猪不得不离去。

SourceText: Is an animal who gets angry when they lose likely to be a good leader?
text: 一个失败就生气的动物可能成为一个好的领导者吗？

SourceText: So far, it looks like the King's contest is removing poor leaders. The contest is working! Who do you think will win?
text: 到目前为止，似乎国王的比赛正在淘汰不合格的领导者。比赛是可行的！你认为谁会赢得比赛？

SourceText: Stories sometimes vary from reality. This story does that in many ways. A boar does not have any fingers! How would a boar be able to clench a spear and throw it? Have you seen other ways this story seems unreal?
text: 故事有时会与现实有所不同。这个故事在很多方面正是如此。野猪压根儿没有手指！一只野猪如何能够握紧长矛并投掷出去呢？你发现了故事中其他看起来虚幻的吗？

SourceText:
After that, the animals started to say things like, "This contest is difficult! Elephant couldn't do it, and he's really big. Boar couldn't do it either, and he's really strong. No one can win this contest!"

Right about then, they heard another sound coming from the back of the crowd. When the animals looked around, they couldn't believe their eyes.
text:
之后，动物们开始了类似这般的议论：“这个比赛太难了！大象都做不到，虽然他很巨大。野猪也做不到，即使他非常强壮。没谁能赢得这场比赛！”

就在那时，他们听到兽群后方又传来一道声音。当动物们环顾四周后，他们简直不敢相信自己的眼睛。

SourceText: What is unusual about the body positions these animals are in?
text: 这些动物的身体姿势有什么不同寻常之处吗？

SourceText: Count the number of animals as best you can. Each animal has two eyes, so you can double that number to find the total number of eyes. You can also count the eyes by skip counting by 2's.
text: 尽你所能数出动物的数量。每只动物有两只眼睛，因此你可以通过将这个数字翻倍来得到眼睛的总数。你也可以按2的倍数跳数来计算眼睛的数量。

SourceText: You can count all the legs by multiplying the number of animals by 4, skip counting by 4, or by doubling the number of eyes! Which do you like best? Why does this work?
text: 你可以通过将动物的数量乘以4、按4的倍数跳数或将眼睛的数量翻倍来计算所有腿的数量。你更喜欢哪种方法？为什么这种方法有效？

SourceText:
They saw a big ape coming forward. As Ape moved, he chanted "I can do it. I know I can do it. I can do it."

Ape took the spear and he backed way up. He pulled his arm back, charged forward, leapt into the air and threw the spear into the sky.

"One! Two! Three! Four! Five! Six! Seven! Oh!" cried Ape.
text:
他们看到一只大猩猩走上前来。随着猩猩的前行，他反复念叨着：“我能做到。我知道我能行。我可以做到。"

猩猩拿过长矛，远远地退后。他手臂后摆，向前一冲，腾空而起，顺势将长矛投向天空。 

“一！二！三！四！五！六！七！哦！”猩猩嘶吼着。

SourceText: Why did Ape start by saying "I can do it?" Having confidence often helps with success.
text: 为什么猩猩最开始要说“我能做到”？拥有信心通常有助于成功。

SourceText: Your attitude can make a big difference! Have you ever started to do something by saying to yourself that you wouldn't be able to do it -- do it help or did it get in your way?
text: 你的态度可能会产生巨大的影响！你是否曾在开始做某事时对自己说做不到？这对你是帮助还是阻碍？

SourceText: How much higher was Ape able to count before the spear landed than Boar could count?
text: 在长矛落地之前，猩猩比野猪多数了多少？

SourceText:
The spear hit the ground on the count of seven.

Ape was upset. He was so angry that he started turning around, complaining and making all sorts of excuses.

But King Leopard told him "No, Ape, you only get one chance." And so the ape had to leave.
text:
长矛在数到七时坠地。

猩猩很沮丧。他异常生气，开始转圈圈，不停地抱怨，找各种借口。

但是豹王正告他：“不可以，猩猩，你只有一次机会。”于是猩猩无奈地走开。

SourceText: So far, no animal has done it. Make up an ending for this story. Either think of a way an animal can win, change the contest, or figure out what to do if no animal can win.
text: 到目前为止，还没有一只动物成功。请为这个故事编造一个结局。可以想象一只动物以某种方式胜出，或更改比赛，或者研究如果没有动物能赢时应该怎么办。

SourceText: How long does it take you to count to ten? Do you think you can throw something in the air long enough to count to ten?
text: 你数到十需要多长时间？你觉得你能把东西抛在空中维持到数十下吗？

SourceText: Use their facial expressions to describe what each of the animals in this picture is feeling.
text: 通过他们的面部表情描述图中每只动物的感受。

SourceText:
Some of the animals turned and started to leave for home. As they were leaving, they saw a little antelope coming through the crowd. As she trotted, she said, "Wait, wait, Let me try. I can do it. I can do it. Let me try."

When the animals heard her words, they all started laughing.
text:
一些动物转身准备回家。在即将离开时，他们看到一只小羚羊穿过兽群而来。她边跑边说：“等等，等一等，让我试试。我能做到。我可以。请让我试一试。”

当动物们听到她的话语时，都开始嘲笑。

SourceText: Why did the other animals laugh at the little antelope? Were they being nice?
text: 其他动物为什么嘲笑小羚羊？他们这样做友好吗？

SourceText: What skill might the antelope have that the others did not?
text: 小羚羊可能具备其他动物没有的哪种技能？

SourceText: Have you ever seen people laugh at someone and just assume that person would do poorly? How did that make the person feel?
text: 你见过人们嘲笑某人并认为那个人会表现不佳吗？这么做会让那人有什么感受？

SourceText: King Leopard jumped up and shouted angrily. "Stop it! Do not make fun of Antelope! Who is to say that small animals can't do things that big animals can do? If Antelope wants to have a chance, she will be given the same chance that all the animals had. So stand back and let Antelope throw the spear."
text: 豹王跳起怒喝道：“住口！不要取笑羚羊！谁说大动物能做的事小动物就不能做？如果羚羊想要尝试，她将得到与所有动物同等的机会。大家让开，让羚羊掷矛吧。”

SourceText: It sounds like there might be a surprise coming. What do you think will be surprising about Antelope?
text: 听起来可能会有惊喜出现。你认为羚羊会有什么令人惊奇的地方？

SourceText: A good leader takes care of everyone. Do you think King Leopard is a good leader?
text: 一个好的领导者会照顾到每一个人。你认为豹王是一个好的领导者吗？

SourceText: Think of a good leader who you know. Describe some qualities that you think make that person a good leader.
text: 想一想你认识的某一位好的领导者。描述一些你认为使那个人成为好领导者的品质。

SourceText:
Antelope bowed to her king, turned and took the spear in her mouth. She backed up, and with all the strength in her tiny body she started running. When she reached the center of the clearing, she jumped high.

She took a deep breath, released the spear and shouted, "Five and five is ten." The spear hit the ground.
text:
羚羊向她的国王鞠躬，转身用嘴巴咬住了长矛。她稍微退后，然后用她小小身体里所有的力量开始奔跑。到达空地中央时，她高高跃起。

她深吸一口气，掷出长矛并大喊道：“五加五等于十。”随后长矛落地。

SourceText: The surprise is Math! Antelope used her intelligence and the power of math to win the contest!
text: 惊喜是数学！羚羊利用她的智慧和数学的力量赢得比赛！

SourceText: Think of some other combinations of numbers that add up to ten. How many ways can you think of?
text: 想一些其他相加得十的数字组合。你能想到多少种？

SourceText: Try some smaller numbers, such as three, four, or five, and find all the ways to make combinations of numbers add up to those totals. Do you notice any patterns that can save you time? Discovering interesting patterns is what math is all about!
text: 尝试一些较小的数字，比如三、四或五，然后找出所有用数字组合相加等于这些总数的方法。你有发现任何可以帮你节省时间的规律吗？探索有趣的规律正是数学的精髓。

SourceText:
The animals were quiet. They were confused. King Leopard explained, "Yes, Antelope! Five plus five is another way to get to ten. There is more than one way to count to ten."

The contest was not to find the biggest or the strongest animal. It was a contest to find the smartest animal! That is how Antelope became queen when leopard died.
text:
兽群寂静无声。他们感到困惑。豹王解释道：“是的，羚羊！五加五是得到十的方法之一。数到十的方法可不止一种。”

这场比赛不是为了找到最大或最强壮的动物。这是一场找出最聪明的动物的比赛！这便是羚羊在豹王去世后成为女王的原因。

SourceText: Antelope listened carefully to the rules and found a new solution. Did Antelope cheat or was she clever?
text: 羚羊仔细听了规则并找到了新的解决方案。是她作弊了还是她聪明呢？

SourceText: If someone asked you to count to ten, would you count by 1's, 2's, 5's, or 10's? What would happen if you counted by 3's or 4's? Why don't those numbers come out evenly?
text: 如果有人让你数到十，你会按1、2、5或10的倍数去数吗？如果你按3或4的倍数数会发生什么？为什么这些数字不能整除？

SourceText: A group of people often all think about something the same way and miss a good way to solve a problem. Good problem solvers discover new ways to approach problems!
text: 同一群体的人经常以相同的方式思考，从而错失解决问题的好方法。优秀的问题解决者会发现解决问题的新途径！

text: 下一个

SourceText: Previous
text: 上一页

text: 完成

text: 隐私政策

text: 模版列表

SourceText: Tour list
text: 巡演列表

text: 重置程序

SourceText: Language
text: 语言

SourceText: EFM App has downloaded an update. Please restart the app to finish installation.
text: EFM 软件已进行了下载和更新。请重启应用程序以完成安装。

SourceText: Restart
text: 重新开始

SourceText:
First and foremost, playing math games should be fun, like any other game your family plays together!

Please let your child make poor plays (mistakes) without correction, and resist the urge to tell them the best ways to play. Bit by bit, your child will get better at the game, and they will learn so much more if you let them figure things out. There is no hurry.

If you see your child make a mistake, ask them to describe why they decided to do what they did. If your child is stuck and doesn't know which play to make, ask them to describe the pros and cons of their choices, or ask them about how they solved a similar situation in the past. If your child doesn't remember how to do a calculation, discuss with them the methods they know for figuring it out. These conversations are important for helping your child to develop mathematically. 

Through math game play and math conversations, you are helping your child learn to enjoy math and develop important problem solving skills!
text:
首先，玩数学游戏是有趣的，就像你与家人一起玩其他游戏一样！

请允许你的孩子没有玩好游戏（在游戏中犯错），不要纠正，也不要急于告诉他们怎么样才是最好的游戏方式。一点一点地，你的孩子会在游戏中变得更擅长，如果你让他们自己把游戏弄清楚，他们将会学到更多。请不要着急。

如果你看到你的孩子犯错，请让他们描述自己为什么选择这样做。如果你的孩子被困住了，并且不知道应该怎么玩，请让他们描述一下他们自己选择的利与弊，或者询问他们过去是怎么解决相似的问题的。如果你的孩子不记得如何计算，和他们讨论如何用他们已知的方法去解决目前的问题。这样的对话对于帮助孩子培养数学思维是很重要的。

通过玩数学游戏和有关数学的对话，你能够帮助你的孩子学会享受数学，并培养对于他们而言很重要的解决问题的能力！

SourceText:
Puzzles are meant to be challenging and to take time, so please don't ruin the fun by telling your child how to do them. These puzzles are chosen so that you can create them easily and then have fun solving them together.

If your child gets stuck on a puzzle, you have several options. You can, of course, give very small hints, if you can think of things that won't give away the puzzle. You can suggest looking at smaller or simpler versions of the puzzle. Encourage your child to be bold in their ideas, even if sometimes they lead to dead ends. We all learn a lot from our mistakes and dead ends! Let your child know that it is perfectly okay not to solve a puzzle on the first (or second or third) try, and that useful ideas may occur to them if they leave the puzzle alone for a day or two.

These puzzles are meant to be fun and to teach problem solving. One of the greatest mathematical pleasures is that AHA moment, after many false starts and much wrestling with a problem, when the answer is finally discovered – be sure to let your child experience that feeling of discovery as many times as you can!
text:
谜题本身就是具有挑战性，且需要花费一定时间的，所以请不要告诉你的孩子怎么做从而破坏了其中的乐趣。选择这些谜题是为了让你可以轻松的创造它们，然后一起解决它们。

如果你的孩子在 一个谜题上卡住了，你有几个选择。当然，你也能在不会泄露解题方法的情况下，给出一些非常小的提示。你可以建议孩子看看更小或更简单的谜题版本。鼓励你的孩子大胆地提出自己的想法，即使有时这些想法会导致死胡同。我们都从错误和死胡同中学到了很多东西！ 让你的孩子知道，在第一次（或第二次，又或者第三次）尝试时，没有解除谜题是完全合理的，如果他们把谜题单独放置一两天，他们可能更容易想到有用的方法。

这些谜题的目的是有趣，并教会如何解决问题。数学最大的乐趣之一是发生在许多错误的开始，和许多与问题的搏斗之后，是当答案最终被发现时顿悟的时刻 — 一定要让你的孩子尽可能多地体验发现的感觉！

SourceText:
Investigations are meant for your child to play with and think about. Let your child explore these looking for interesting patterns and beautiful relationships. Resist the temptation to unveil what is going on and give the answer. If your child seems to have reached a dead end, suggest that they come back to the investigation at a future time to play with it again.

Many investigations benefit from organizing results, and this is a great thing for you to help your child with. Help them make tables, drawings, or whatever may help them see more easily what is going on. And of course, it is perfectly fine to give them gentle nudges from time to time in the right direction. Remember that your child will learn a lot by developing persistence and learning how to look more deeply at things.
text:
探索是为了让你的孩子能在玩的时候思考。让你的孩子探索这些有趣的规律和美丽的关联。抵制住想要揭开真相并给出答案的欲望。如果你的孩子似乎进入了死胡同，可以建议他们在未来的时间再回来继续玩与探索它。

有条理的探索更有益于学习，这也是你可以参与帮助他们的事情之一。帮助他们制作表格，绘图，或任何可以帮助他们理解正在发生的事情的方法。当然，在正确的方向上时不时地推动他们是完全没问题的。记住，你的孩子会通过培养毅力和学习如何更深入地看待事物，而学到很多东西。

SourceText: Before Talking
text: 学说话以前

SourceText: Talk with your child before they can talk or even understand the words. Point at, name, and describe things you see, such as shapes, colors, comparisons, and quantities. As your child begins to understand words, ask about a thing and have your child point at it. For example, "Where is the ball?" If your child can't find the thing, point to it for them.
text: 在你的孩子学会说话以及了解文字之前先与他们聊一聊。指向、说出名称和描述你所看到的事物，例如形状、颜色、比较和数量。当你的孩子开始理解单词时，对你的孩子说出一个名词并且让你的孩子指向和那个名词对应的事物。例如，“球在哪里？”如果你的孩子找不到那一样东西，请指给他们看。

SourceText: Early Talking
text: 初期对话

SourceText: As your child begins to understand and say words, mix in simple questions. Freely help with answers as needed. If you point and say "Is this red?" and they don't know, supply the answer. If you say "Count the blocks." and your child does not know how, point and count the blocks with them "one, two, three."
text: 当你的孩子开始理解和说单词时，融入一些简单的问题。根据需要给予帮助。当你指着一个事物说“这是红色的吗？”如果他们不知道，就为他们提供答案。当你说“我们来数一数积木，”如果你的孩子不知道如何数数，带着他们一边拿着积木一边数“一、二、三。”

SourceText: 3 Levels of Discussion
text: 3个讨论级别

SourceText:
Pick an appropriate level for your child. Allow time for thought when asking questions or making comments. Help with the answer when your child stumbles, and follow up correct answers with questions or comments that are small expansions on the child's answer. 

**Level 1** Ask simple direct questions. Ask and point at what you see on the page. Where is the toy? What are they doing? What is its name? What color is it? How many balls are there? 
**Level 2** Ask general or open questions about this point in the story. What do you see happening here? What is this group of things? 
**Level 3** Ask about the story line. What has happened? What will happen next? Have you had experiences or seen things similar to this? How does she feel when this happens?
text:
为你的孩子选择一个合适他们程度的级别。让你的孩子有充足的思考和提出发问的时间。在你的孩子解答问题产生困难的时候给予适当的协助，并在正确答案解出以后再加上简单的问题或评论，这些问题或评论将会成为答案的小幅延伸。

**级别1** 提出简单直接的问题。对于你在页面上看到的内容向你的孩子提出问题。玩具在哪里？它们在做什么？玩具的名字是什么？它是什么颜色？那里有多少球？
**级别2** 就故事中的某一点提出一般性或开放性问题。你看到这里发生了什么？这组东西是什么？
**级别3** 询问故事情节。刚才发生了什么事？接下来会发生什么？你有过类似的经历或者目睹过如此的事情吗？当这种情况发生时，她会有什么样的感受？

SourceText: Read, Talk, and Have Fun!
text: 愉快的阅读和谈论！

SourceText:
The supplied questions and comments are just the beginning. 

1. For the first reading, read the red questions and comments. 
2. For the second reading, read the blue questions and comments. 
3. For the third reading, read the green questions and comments. 

After that, follow your child's interests and let your discussions go in fun directions.
text:
这里提供的问题和评论只是一个开始。

第一次阅读，请看涂红色的问题和评论。
第二次阅读，请看涂蓝色的问题和评论。
第三次阅读，请看涂绿色的问题和评论。

之后，跟随着孩子的兴趣，让你们的讨论朝着有趣的方向发展。

SourceText: Some of the activities have additional material with examples and further explanations. You can look at them here or at the end of the corresponding activity page.

SourceText: Each of the Stages has about a dozen sections of fun games, puzzles, activities, and investigations for your family to enjoy together.
text: 每个阶段大约包含十几个部分，提供有趣的游戏、拼图、活动和探索，供全家一起娱乐。

SourceText: Stages
text: 阶段

SourceText: Each Stage name describes the main requirement for your child to start that Stage. For example, if your child can count to ten, and knows what those numbers mean, then start with Stage 3. The materials in the Stages are designed in a learning progression so that later sections build on the earlier ones.
text: 每个阶段的名称都描述了孩子开始该阶段的主要要求。例如，如果你的孩子能数到十并理解这些数字的含义，那么可以从第三阶段开始。各个阶段的材料按照学习进阶的顺序设计，后面的部分是基于前面内容的延续和升华。

SourceText: Please select the kinds of activities you would like to do.
text: 请选择您想进行的活动类型。

SourceText: Please select whether you would rather view the Stage activities individually or by topic.
text: 请选择您是希望按单个阶段查看活动，还是按主题查看活动。

SourceText: Each Stage of learning is divided into ten basic learning steps. Each step describes what your child is learning, how you can help with that learning, and how the steps are connected with each other.
text: 每个学习阶段分为十个基本的学习步骤。每个步骤都会说明您的孩子在学习什么、您如何帮助他们学习，以及这些步骤之间的关联性。

SourceText: Each Stage has ten playdates for your family to enjoy with a group of other families. Each playdate has suggested storybooks and activities to enjoy together during the playdate. The playdates correspond to the ten math learning steps for each Stage. Links are provided to give direct and easy access to each of those resources.
text: 每个阶段都有十个游戏，供您和其他家庭一起享受。每个游戏都推荐了适合一起阅读的故事书和活动。这些游戏对应于每个阶段的十个数学学习步骤。每个游戏都提供了链接，便于您直接访问这些资源。

SourceText: Reading with your child is a wonderful experience! These storybooks are for an adult to read to a child. Adding math comments and questions to your reading helps your child grow mathematically, and creates strong associations of math with this happy, cozy experience.
text: 与孩子一起阅读是美好的体验！这些故事书是为成人给孩子朗读准备的。在阅读过程中加入数学相关的评论和问题，不仅能帮助孩子的数学成长，还能让数学与这种快乐、温馨的经历紧密联系起来。

SourceText: Please select the kinds of stories you would like to choose from.
text: 请选择您想选择的故事类型。

SourceText: Beginning Storybooks
text: 初级故事书

SourceText: Talk with your child before they can talk or even understand the words. Point at, name, and describe things you see, such as shapes, colors, comparisons, and quantities. As your child begins to understand words, ask about a thing and have your child point at it. As your child begins to understand and say words, mix in simple questions.
text: 在孩子还不会说话甚至不理解单词时，就可以与他们交流。指着你看到的事物，告诉他们名称并进行描述，比如形状、颜色、大小比较和数量。当孩子开始理解单词时，可以提问并让他们指出对应的物品。等孩子开始理解并会说单词后，可以逐渐加入一些简单的问题。

SourceText: Intermediate Storybooks
text: 中级故事书

SourceText: These storybooks are somewhat longer, have slightly more complex story lines, and involve more sophisticated ideas. Your child is now able to talk and reason about more things in the world.
text: 这些故事书篇幅稍长，故事情节更复杂，涵盖的思想也更深入。您的孩子现在能够讨论并思考更多世界上的事物。

SourceText: Advanced Storybooks
text: 高级故事书

SourceText: The story lines are getting ever more detailed and complex. The math involves larger numbers and more advanced concepts. The description of objects is getting more detailed and involved.
text: 故事情节变得更加详细和复杂，数学内容涉及更大的数字和更高级的概念。对物体的描述也更加细致且深入。

SourceText: Welcome!
text: 欢迎！

SourceText: Enjoy reading and playing with math together! The best way to learn and experience math is in a social and playful way. Early Family Math has created four kinds of materials for your family to enjoy together.
text: 一起享受阅读和数学游戏吧！最好的学习和体验数学的方式就是在社交和游戏中进行。Early Family Math 为您的家庭准备了四种可以共同学习的材料。

SourceText: Storybooks
text: 故事书

SourceText: These storybooks are for an adult to read to a child. They have math comments and guiding questions on every page. Help your child grow mathematically and create strong associations of math with the happy, cozy experience of reading together!
text: 这些故事书是为成人给孩子朗读的。每一页都有数学评论和引导性问题。通过一起阅读，帮助孩子数学能力的成长，并将数学与这种愉快、温馨的阅读体验紧密联系起来！

SourceText: Activities
text: 活动

SourceText: These educationally sequenced math games, puzzles, activities, and investigations, designed for your family to play together, provide lots of enjoyable family time as your child learns all the math they need for school.
text: 这些按教育顺序设计的数学游戏、拼图、活动和探索，旨在让全家一起参与。不仅能帮助孩子学习学校所需的数学知识，还能为家庭带来许多欢乐的时光。

SourceText: Math Learning Steps
text: 数学学习步骤

SourceText: Have you ever wondered what the beginning learning steps are for math, and how they connect with each other? Here are brief descriptions of the ten math learning steps your child will be experiencing as they go through each of the five Stages.
text: 你有没有想过，数学的初始学习步骤是什么，以及它们之间是如何相互联系的？下面是十个数学学习步骤的简要介绍，您的孩子将在五个阶段中逐步体验这些步骤。

SourceText: Playdates
text: 游戏聚会

SourceText: Get together with other families and have a math playdate. These playdates have suggested storybooks, games, and puzzles for your group of families to enjoy together.
text: 和其他家庭一起举办数学游戏聚会吧！这些聚会提供推荐的故事书、游戏和拼图，供多个家庭共同享受和互动。

SourceText: Help
text: 帮助

SourceText: If you ever want to see this introduction again, just click on the question mark.
text: 如果您想再次查看此介绍，点击问号标识即可。
